# Brandenburg Gate

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

This article is about the gate in Berlin. For other uses, see [Brandenburg
Gate (disambiguation)](/wiki/Brandenburg_Gate_\(disambiguation\) "Brandenburg
Gate \(disambiguation\)").

The **Brandenburg Gate** ([German](/wiki/German_language "German language"):
_Brandenburger Tor_) is an 18th-century
[neoclassical](/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture "Neoclassical architecture")
monument in [Berlin](/wiki/Berlin "Berlin"), built on the orders of
[Prussian](/wiki/Prussia "Prussia") king [Frederick William
II](/wiki/Frederick_William_II_of_Prussia "Frederick William II of Prussia")
after the (temporarily) successful restoration of order during the early
[Batavian Revolution](/wiki/Batavian_Revolution "Batavian Revolution").[1] One
of the best-known landmarks of [Germany](/wiki/Germany "Germany"), it was
built on the site of a former [city gate](/wiki/City_gate "City gate") that
marked the start of the road from Berlin to the town of [Brandenburg an der
Havel](/wiki/Brandenburg_an_der_Havel "Brandenburg an der Havel"), which used
to be capital of the [Margraviate of
Brandenburg](/wiki/Margraviate_of_Brandenburg "Margraviate of Brandenburg").

It is located in the western part of the city centre of Berlin within
[Mitte](/wiki/Mitte_\(locality\) "Mitte \(locality\)"), at the junction of
[Unter den Linden](/wiki/Unter_den_Linden "Unter den Linden") and
[Ebertstraße](/wiki/Ebertstra%C3%9Fe "Ebertstraße"), immediately west of the
[Pariser Platz](/wiki/Pariser_Platz "Pariser Platz"). One block to the north
stands the [Reichstag building](/wiki/Reichstag_building "Reichstag
building"), which houses the German parliament (_[Bundestag](/wiki/Bundestag
"Bundestag")_). The gate is the monumental entry to Unter den Linden, the
renowned boulevard of [linden](/wiki/Tilia "Tilia") trees, which led directly
to the royal [City Palace](/wiki/City_Palace,_Berlin "City Palace, Berlin") of
the [Prussian](/wiki/Prussia "Prussia") monarchs.

Throughout its existence, the Brandenburg Gate was often a site for major
historical events and is today considered not only as a symbol of the
tumultuous history of Europe and Germany, but also of European
[unity](/wiki/European_integration "European integration") and
[peace](/wiki/Long_Peace "Long Peace").

### Design and
construction[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Brandenburg_Gate&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Design and construction")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/ZLB-
Berliner_Ansichten-Januar.jpg/220px-ZLB-Berliner_Ansichten-
Januar.jpg)](/wiki/File:ZLB-Berliner_Ansichten-Januar.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:ZLB-Berliner_Ansichten-Januar.jpg "Enlarge")

Berlin in 1688: The future site of the Brandenburg gate was near the middle
left of the map, separating the [Tiergarten](/wiki/Tiergarten_\(park\)
"Tiergarten \(park\)") from [Unter den Linden](/wiki/Unter_den_Linden "Unter
den Linden"). Travellers going west from the city toward [Brandenburg an der
Havel](/wiki/Brandenburg_an_der_Havel "Brandenburg an der Havel") could pass
in this direction

In the time of [Frederick William](/wiki/Frederick_William_I_of_Prussia
"Frederick William I of Prussia") (1688), shortly after the [Thirty Years'
War](/wiki/Thirty_Years%27_War "Thirty Years' War") and a century before the
gate was constructed, Berlin was a small walled city within a [star
fort](/wiki/Star_fort "Star fort") with several named gates:
[Spandauer](/wiki/Spandau "Spandau") Tor, St. Georgen Tor, Stralower Tor,
[Cöpenicker](/wiki/K%C3%B6penick "Köpenick") Tor, Neues Tor, and
[Leipziger](/wiki/Leipzig "Leipzig") Tor _(see map)_. Relative peace, a policy
of religious tolerance, and status as capital of the [Kingdom of
Prussia](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Prussia "Kingdom of Prussia") facilitated the growth
of the city.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Karte_berlin_akzisemauer.png/220px-
Karte_berlin_akzisemauer.png)](/wiki/File:Karte_berlin_akzisemauer.png)

[](/wiki/File:Karte_berlin_akzisemauer.png "Enlarge")

The [Berlin Customs Wall](/wiki/Berlin_Customs_Wall "Berlin Customs Wall")
with its 18 gates

The Brandenburg Gate was not part of the old [Berlin
Fortress](/wiki/Berlin_Fortress "Berlin Fortress"), but one of 18 gates within
the [Berlin Customs Wall](/wiki/Berlin_Customs_Wall "Berlin Customs Wall")
([German](/wiki/German_language "German language"):
_[Akzisemauer](https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Akzisemauer "de:Akzisemauer")_),
erected in the 1730s, including the old fortified city and many of its then
suburbs.

The new gate was commissioned by [Frederick William II of
Prussia](/wiki/Frederick_William_II_of_Prussia "Frederick William II of
Prussia") to represent peace. The Gate was designed by [Carl Gotthard
Langhans](/wiki/Carl_Gotthard_Langhans "Carl Gotthard Langhans"), the Court
Superintendent of Buildings, and built between 1788 and 1791, replacing the
earlier simple guardhouses which flanked the original gate in the Customs
Wall. The gate consists of twelve [Doric](/wiki/Doric_order "Doric order")
columns, six to each side, forming five passageways. Citizens originally were
allowed to use only the outermost two on each side. Atop the gate is a
[Quadriga](/wiki/Quadriga "Quadriga"), a chariot drawn by four horses,
sculpted by [Johann Gottfried Schadow](/wiki/Johann_Gottfried_Schadow "Johann
Gottfried Schadow"). The new gate was originally named the Peace Gate (German:
_Friedenstor_)[2] and the goddess is [Victoria](/wiki/Victoria_\(mythology\)
"Victoria \(mythology\)"), the goddess of victory.

The gate's design is based upon the [Propylaea](/wiki/Propylaea "Propylaea"),
the gateway to the [Acropolis](/wiki/Acropolis "Acropolis") in
[Athens](/wiki/Athens "Athens"), Greece, and is consistent with Berlin's
history of architectural [classicism](/wiki/Classicism "Classicism") (first,
[Baroque](/wiki/Baroque "Baroque"), and then [neo-Palladian](/wiki/Neo-
Palladian "Neo-Palladian")). The gate was the first element of "Athens on the
River Spree" by architect Langhans.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

### 19th and early 20th
centuries[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Brandenburg_Gate&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: 19th and early 20th centuries")]

The Brandenburg Gate has played different political roles in German history.
After the 1806 Prussian defeat at the [Battle of Jena-
Auerstedt](/wiki/Battle_of_Jena-Auerstedt "Battle of Jena-Auerstedt"),
[Napoleon](/wiki/Napoleon "Napoleon") was the first to use the Brandenburg
Gate for a triumphal procession,[3] and took its Quadriga to Paris.[4]

After Napoleon's defeat in 1814 and the Prussian occupation of Paris by
General [Ernst von Pfuel](/wiki/Ernst_von_Pfuel "Ernst von Pfuel"), the
Quadriga was restored to Berlin.[5] It was now redesigned by [Karl Friedrich
Schinkel](/wiki/Karl_Friedrich_Schinkel "Karl Friedrich Schinkel") for the new
role of the Brandenburg Gate as a Prussian triumphal arch; the goddess, now
definitely Victoria, was equipped with the Prussian eagle and [Iron
Cross](/wiki/Iron_Cross "Iron Cross") on her lance with a wreath of oak
leaves.[2]

The Quadriga faces east, as it did when it was originally installed in 1793.
Only the royal family was allowed to pass through the central archway,[4] as
well as members of the [Pfuel](/wiki/Pfuel "Pfuel") family, from 1814 to
1919.[6][7] The Kaiser granted this honour to the family in gratitude to Ernst
von Pfuel, who had overseen the return of the Quadriga to the top of the
gate.[8] In addition, the central archway was also used by the coaches of
ambassadors on the single occasion of their presenting their [letters of
credence](/wiki/Diplomatic_correspondence#Letters_of_credence "Diplomatic
correspondence") to council.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Allies_at_the_Brandenburg_Gate%2C_1945.jpg/220px-
Allies_at_the_Brandenburg_Gate%2C_1945.jpg)](/wiki/File:Allies_at_the_Brandenburg_Gate,_1945.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Allies_at_the_Brandenburg_Gate,_1945.jpg "Enlarge")

[Bernard Montgomery](/wiki/Bernard_Montgomery "Bernard Montgomery") and Soviet
Marshals [Zhukov](/wiki/Georgy_Zhukov "Georgy Zhukov") and
[Rokossovsky](/wiki/Konstantin_Rokossovsky "Konstantin Rokossovsky") leave the
Brandenburg Gate on 12 July 1945 after being decorated by Montgomery

When the [Nazis](/wiki/Nazis "Nazis") ascended to power, they used the gate as
a party symbol. The gate survived World War II and was one of the damaged
structures still standing in the Pariser Platz ruins in 1945 (another being
the Academy of Fine Arts). The gate was badly damaged with holes in the
columns from bullets and nearby explosions. One horse’s head from the original
quadriga survived, and is today kept in the collection of the [Märkisches
Museum](/wiki/M%C3%A4rkisches_Museum "Märkisches Museum").

### Cold War[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Brandenburg_Gate&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Cold War")]

Following Germany's surrender and the end of the war, the governments of [East
Berlin](/wiki/East_Berlin "East Berlin") and [West Berlin](/wiki/West_Berlin
"West Berlin") restored it in a joint effort. The holes were patched, but were
visible for many years following the war.

Vehicles and pedestrians could travel freely through the gate, located in East
Berlin, until the [Berlin Wall](/wiki/Berlin_Wall "Berlin Wall") was built, 13
August 1961. Brandenburg Gate border crossing was later closed on 14 August
1961. West Berliners gathered on the western side of the gate to demonstrate
against the Berlin Wall, among them West Berlin's governing Mayor [Willy
Brandt](/wiki/Willy_Brandt "Willy Brandt"), who had spontaneously returned
from a federal election campaigning tour in West Germany earlier on the same
day. It was closed throughout the [Berlin Wall](/wiki/Berlin_Wall "Berlin
Wall") period until 22 December 1989.

### Post-1989[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Brandenburg_Gate&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Post-1989")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Crane_removed_part_of_Wall_Brandenburg_Gate.jpg/220px-
Crane_removed_part_of_Wall_Brandenburg_Gate.jpg)](/wiki/File:Crane_removed_part_of_Wall_Brandenburg_Gate.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Crane_removed_part_of_Wall_Brandenburg_Gate.jpg "Enlarge")

A crane removes a section of the [Berlin Wall](/wiki/Berlin_Wall "Berlin
Wall") near Brandenburg Gate on 21 December 1989

When the [Revolutions of 1989](/wiki/Revolutions_of_1989 "Revolutions of
1989") occurred and the wall was demolished, the gate symbolized freedom and
the desire to unify the city of Berlin. Thousands of people gathered at the
wall to celebrate its fall on 9 November 1989. On 22 December 1989, the
Brandenburg Gate border crossing was reopened when [Helmut
Kohl](/wiki/Helmut_Kohl "Helmut Kohl"), the West German chancellor, walked
through to be greeted by [Hans Modrow](/wiki/Hans_Modrow "Hans Modrow"), the
East German prime minister. Demolition of the rest of the wall around the area
took place the following year.

During 1990, the quadriga was removed from the gate as part of renovation work
carried out by the East German authorities following the fall of the wall in
November 1989. Germany was officially reunified in October 1990.

The Brandenburg Gate was privately refurbished on 21 December 2000, at a cost
of six million euros. It was once again opened on 3 October 2002 following
extensive refurbishment, for the 12th anniversary of [German
reunification](/wiki/German_reunification "German reunification").

Brandenburg Gate became the main venue for the 20th-anniversary celebrations
of the fall of the Berlin Wall or "Festival of Freedom" on the evening of 9
November 2009. The high point of the celebrations was when over 1000
colorfully designed foam domino tiles, each over 2.5 m tall, were lined up
along the route of the former wall through the city centre. The domino "wall"
was then toppled in stages converging here.[9]

The Brandenburg Gate is now again closed to vehicle traffic, and much of
Pariser Platz has been turned into a [cobblestone](/wiki/Cobblestone
"Cobblestone") [pedestrian zone](/wiki/Pedestrian_zone "Pedestrian zone"). The
gate, along with the broad _[Straße des 17.
Juni](/wiki/Stra%C3%9Fe_des_17._Juni "Straße des 17. Juni")_ avenue to the
west, is also one of the large public areas in Berlin where over a million
people can gather to watch stage shows or party together, watch major sport
events shown on huge screens, or see fireworks at midnight on New Year's
Eve.[10] After winning the [2014 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup
"2014 FIFA World Cup"), the [Germany national football
team](/wiki/Germany_national_football_team "Germany national football team")
held their victory rally in front of the gate.

It has also hosted street events at [2009 IAAF World Championships in
Athletics](/wiki/2009_IAAF_World_Championships_in_Athletics "2009 IAAF World
Championships in Athletics") and will repeat its role in [2018 European
Athletics Championships](/wiki/2018_European_Athletics_Championships "2018
European Athletics Championships"). It is also the usual finish line of the
[Berlin Marathon](/wiki/Berlin_Marathon "Berlin Marathon").

## Political
history[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Brandenburg_Gate&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Political history")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/ReaganBerlinWall.jpg/220px-
ReaganBerlinWall.jpg)](/wiki/File:ReaganBerlinWall.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:ReaganBerlinWall.jpg "Enlarge")

[Ronald Reagan](/wiki/Ronald_Reagan "Ronald Reagan") speaks at the [Berlin
Wall](/wiki/Berlin_Wall "Berlin Wall")'s _Brandenburg Gate_ on June 12, 1987,
challenging [Gorbachev](/wiki/Mikhail_Gorbachev "Mikhail Gorbachev") to "[tear
down this wall!](/wiki/Tear_down_this_wall! "Tear down this wall!")!"

![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/50px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png) |  [_Tear down this wall_](/wiki/File:Reagan_Brandenburg_Gate_speech.ogg "File:Reagan Brandenburg Gate speech.ogg") ![](data:image/png,%89PNG%0D%0A%1A%0A%00%00%00%0DIHDR%00%00%00%01%00%00%00%01%08%02%00%00%00%90wS%DE%00%00%00%01sRGB%00%AE%CE%1C%E9%00%00%00%09pHYs%00%00%0B%13%00%00%0B%13%01%00%9A%9C%18%00%00%00%07tIME%07%DB%0B%0A%17%041%80%9B%E7%F2%00%00%00%19tEXtComment%00Created%20with%20GIMPW%81%0E%17%00%00%00%0CIDAT%08%D7c%60%60%60%00%00%00%04%00%01'4'%0A%00%00%00%00IEND%AEB%60%82)[](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/7/73/Reagan_Brandenburg_Gate_speech.ogg/Reagan_Brandenburg_Gate_speech.ogg.mp3) Complete speech by [Ronald Reagan](/wiki/Ronald_Reagan "Ronald Reagan") at the Brandenburg Gate, 12 June 1987

A Soviet flag flew from a flagpole atop the gate from 1945 until 1957, when it
was replaced by an East German flag. Since the reunification of Germany, the
flag and the pole have been removed.

In 1963, U.S. President [John F. Kennedy](/wiki/John_F._Kennedy "John F.
Kennedy") visited the Brandenburg Gate. The Soviets hung large red banners
across it to prevent him looking into East Berlin.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

In the 1980s, decrying the existence of two German states and two Berlins,
West Berlin mayor [Richard von Weizsäcker](/wiki/Richard_von_Weizs%C3%A4cker
"Richard von Weizsäcker") said: "The German question is open as long as the
Brandenburg Gate is closed."[11]

On 12 June 1987, U.S. President [Ronald Reagan](/wiki/Ronald_Reagan "Ronald
Reagan") spoke to the West Berlin populace at the Brandenburg Gate, demanding
the razing of the Berlin Wall.[12][13] Addressing the [General Secretary of
the Communist Party of the Soviet
Union](/wiki/General_Secretary_of_the_Communist_Party_of_the_Soviet_Union
"General Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union"), [Mikhail
Gorbachev](/wiki/Mikhail_Gorbachev "Mikhail Gorbachev"), Reagan said,

> General Secretary Gorbachev, if you seek peace, if you seek prosperity for
> the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, if you seek liberalization: Come here
> to this gate! Mr. Gorbachev, open this gate! Mr. Gorbachev, [tear down this
> wall](/wiki/Tear_down_this_wall "Tear down this wall")!

On 25 December 1989, less than two months after the Berlin Wall began to come
down, the conductor [Leonard Bernstein](/wiki/Leonard_Bernstein "Leonard
Bernstein") conducted the [Berlin Philharmonic](/wiki/Berlin_Philharmonic
"Berlin Philharmonic") in a version of the [Ninth
Symphony](/wiki/Symphony_No._9_\(Beethoven\) "Symphony No. 9 \(Beethoven\)")
of [Beethoven](/wiki/Beethoven "Beethoven") at the then newly opened
Brandenburg Gate. In the concluding choral movement of the symphony, the
famous "Ode to Joy", the word _Freude_ ("Joy") was replaced with _Freiheit_
("Freedom") to celebrate the fall of the Wall and the imminent reunification
of [Germany](/wiki/Germany "Germany").

On 2–3 October 1990, the Gate was the scene of the official ceremony to mark
the [reunification of Germany](/wiki/German_reunification "German
reunification"). At the stroke of midnight on 3 October, the [black-red-gold
flag of West Germany](/wiki/Flag_of_Germany "Flag of Germany")—now the flag of
a reunified Germany—was raised over the Gate.

On 12 July 1994, U.S. President [Bill Clinton](/wiki/Bill_Clinton "Bill
Clinton") spoke at the Gate about peace in post–Cold War Europe.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/U2_at_the_Brandenburg_Gate.jpg/220px-U2_at_the_Brandenburg_Gate.jpg)](/wiki/File:U2_at_the_Brandenburg_Gate.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:U2_at_the_Brandenburg_Gate.jpg "Enlarge")

Twentieth anniversary celebrations of the [Fall of the
Wall](/wiki/Fall_of_the_Berlin_Wall "Fall of the Berlin Wall") at Brandenburg
Gate on 9 November 2009, featuring a performance by [Paul van
Dyk](/wiki/Paul_van_Dyk "Paul van Dyk")[14]

On 9 November 2009, Chancellor [Angela Merkel](/wiki/Angela_Merkel "Angela
Merkel"), walked through Brandenburg Gate with Russia’s Mikhail Gorbachev and
Poland's [Lech Wałęsa](/wiki/Lech_Wa%C5%82%C4%99sa "Lech Wałęsa") as part of
the 20-year celebration of tearing down the Berlin Wall.[15][16]

On 13 August 2011, Germany marked the 50th anniversary of the day the Berlin
Wall started to go up with a memorial service and a minute of silence in
memory of those who died trying to flee to the West. "It is our shared
responsibility to keep the memory alive and to pass it on to the coming
generations as a reminder to stand up for freedom and democracy to ensure that
such injustice may never happen again," Berlin Mayor [Klaus
Wowereit](/wiki/Klaus_Wowereit "Klaus Wowereit") said. German Chancellor
Angela Merkel—who grew up behind the wall in Germany's communist eastern
part—also attended the commemoration. German President [Christian
Wulff](/wiki/Christian_Wulff "Christian Wulff") added, "It has been shown once
again: Freedom is invincible at the end. No wall can permanently withstand the
desire for freedom."[17][18][19]

On 19 June 2013, U.S. President [Barack Obama](/wiki/Barack_Obama "Barack
Obama") spoke at the Gate about nuclear arms reduction and the recently
revealed U.S. internet surveillance activities.[20]

On the night of 5 January 2015, the lights illuminating the gate were
completely shut off in protest against a protest held by far-right anti-
Islamic group [Pegida](/wiki/Pegida "Pegida").[21][22][23]

In April 2017, [Die Zeit](/wiki/Die_Zeit "Die Zeit") noted that the gate was
not illuminated in Russian colours after the [2017 Saint Petersburg Metro
bombing](/wiki/2017_Saint_Petersburg_Metro_bombing "2017 Saint Petersburg
Metro bombing"). The gate was previously illuminated after attacks in
Jerusalem and Orlando. The Berlin Senate only lets the gate be illuminated for
events in partner cities and cities with a special connection to Berlin.[24]
